quote: Captain's Log, Stardate 46915.2.   The Enterprise is orbiting Nervala   Four, waiting for an opportunity   to retrieve scientific data left   there by Starfleet researchers   when they were forced to evacuate   eight years ago.
Thank you... thank you very much.
Any requests tonight?
Night Bird.
Anyone?
Night Bird!
Ladies and Gentlemen... Night   Bird.
What was that all about?
Wil's been trying to get this   piece right for ten years now.   He's never made it through the   solo.
Remember that dance recital I told   you I was doing?
Next week.
You're dis-invited.
Here it comes.
Data to Commander Riker.
Riker, here.
Commander, you are needed on the   Bridge.
On my way.
Saved by the bell...
You wanted to see me, Data?
Yes, sir. It appears that we will   be able to transport to the   surface sooner than we   anticipated.
Is the planet's distortion field   de-phasing sooner than you   predicted?
No, sir. But using the Potemkin's   transport logs from the original   evacuation, Commander La Forge and   I were able to modify the   Transporters.
So we can beam through higher   distortion levels.
The Transporters are now   considerably more efficient than   those used on the Potemkin eight   years ago.
Glad to hear it. I almost didn't   make it off the surface that day.       When can we get started?
Ninety-seven minutes.
How long will the transport window   last?
Twenty-six minutes. After that,   the distortion field will re-phase.
That doesn't give us much time to   retrieve the database.
The planet's proximity to its sun   will create two additional   transport windows in the next   three days.
Let's hope that's enough.
It will have to be. The next   transport window will not occur   for another eight years, when the   planet's orbit brings it close   enough to the sun to de-phase the   distortion field.
Notify the Away Team we're going   in ahead of schedule; I'll tell   the Captain.
How long until the transport   window opens?
Fourteen seconds.
Let's get in position.
Whenever you're ready, Commander.
Energize.
This isn't how I remember it; the   place was a mess when we left.
Commander...
Someone's been here...
A vessel could have gotten caught   in the distortion field and   crashed. The survivors may have   taken shelter here.
Commander, someone is   approaching... a humanoid. Forty   meters due east and closing.
Who are you?
Who are you?
Commander William Riker of the   Federation Starship Enterprise.
That's not possible. I'm Wil   Riker.
May I ask how you got here?
Eight years ago, I led a team to   evacuate this station.
What ship were you on?
The Potemkin.
Why did you not return to the   Potemkin with the others?

I was the last one out. The   distortion field must have   interfered with the transport;   they lost their signal lock on me.   When I tried to contact the ship,   I couldn't get through the   interference.
Check with Starfleet; I'm sure   they recorded me lost that day.
That's not what happened. I was   the last one out... but I made it   back to the Potemkin.
You don't believe me.
It's not that we don't believe   you; it's just hard to see how   both our stories could be true.       Would you be willing to let our   Doctor check you out?
Of course.
Lieutenant Worf, take him to   Sickbay. Notify the Captain as   soon as you're aboard.
Worf to Enterprise. Two to beam   up.
Let's get to work.
Looks like you fractured your arm   a few years ago.
I was underneath the station   making repairs when an earthquake   hit -- I got caught in a   rockslide. I had to set it   myself.
Captain Jean-Luc Picard.
Lieutenant Wil Riker, sir.
If you are Wil Riker, if there are   two of you... then something   extraordinary has occurred. I   hope you understand our need to   verify your claim.
Yes, sir.
Genetically, he's   indistinguishable from Commander   Riker.
Could some sort of cloning be   involved?
I don't think so, there's no   genetic drift.
But that isn't conclusive.
That's why I compared their brain   scans. Brain organization   patterns are as unique as...   fingerprints. Except for some   minor differences, theirs are   identical.
Can't brain patterns be cloned?
No. They're determined by   experience, mostly in early   childhood.
How could two men have shared the   same childhood experiences? It   doesn't make any sense.
Sir, I am Wil Riker. I don't know   who or what made it back to the   Potemkin that day, but it wasn't   me.
Lieutenant -- my Chief Engineer is   checking over the transport logs   from the Potemkin. They may shed   some light on what happened.
Yes, sir.
Don't worry, we'll get to the   bottom of this.
In the meantime you'll be taken to   quarters. Make yourself   comfortable.
I will, sir. The replicators on   the station stopped working a long   time ago. It's been a while since   I had a decent meal.
Doctor...

... apparently there was a massive   energy surge in the distortion   field around the planet just at   the moment you tried to beam out.   The Transporter Chief tried to   compensate by initiating a second   containment beam.
An interesting approach. He must   have been planning to reintegrate   the two patterns in the transport   buffer.
Turns out he didn't have to.   Commander Riker's pattern   maintained its integrity with just   the one containment beam -- he   made it back to the ship just   fine.
What happened to the second beam?
The Transporter Chief shut it   down, but somehow... it was   reflected back to the surface.
And another Wil Riker materialized   there.
How could the second pattern have   maintained its integrity?
The containment beam must have had   the exact same phase differential   as the distortion field.
Which one of us is... real?
Both. You were both re-materialized   from a complete   pattern.
Up to that moment, you were the   same person.
But over the last eight years, you   and...
-- Lieutenant Riker have lived   very different lives. You're   different people now.
For us, it's a little like meeting   a close friend's twin. You can't   help feeling that you know them...   but of course you don't.
No matter how strange it may seem   to us... there are now two Wil   Rikers aboard this vessel.   Getting used to the idea may take   a while... especially for you,   Wil.
I'll be all right, sir.
Lieutenant Riker will be here for   a few days at least. We should do   everything we can to make him feel   comfortable and welcome.
That still leaves us with the   problem of how to retrieve the   database. The station's computer   is only partially operational.
Many of its components have been   removed. Apparently Lieutenant   Riker used them to keep the   station's radiation shield   operational.
Can we repair it, at least enough   to access the database?
Without knowing what he did, it'll   be tough.
Maybe he could help?
He was alone down there a long   time. I'm hesitant to send him   back until he's been evaluated.
I'll talk to him.
Thank you, Counselor.
Come in.
Hello, Wil.
Imzadi...
Wil...
I thought I'd never see you   again...
We need to talk.
You're here... on this ship...   because of him.
No.
Commander Riker and I are friends,   close friends; nothing more.
Wil -- why don't we sit down?
Do you remember the last time we   saw each other?
Like yesterday. We spent the day   at the Janaran falls, on Betazed.
It was the day before you started   your tour on the Potemkin.
We were going to meet six weeks   later, on Risa.
We never did.
I know.
What I mean is... Commander Riker   and I never did.
You see... he earned a promotion   very quickly.
I know.       For exceptional valor during the   evacuation of the research station   on Nervala Four.       I looked over his service record.
He chose to make his career a   priority. There wasn't time for   much of anything else.
We kept in touch... but we didn't   see each other again until we were   both posted to the Enterprise two   years later.
By then, our feelings for each   other had changed. We've served   together for six years now...   things never went back to the way   they used to be.
I had a lot of time on my hands   down there. There were days I   felt so alone I thought I might   lose my mind.
Do you know what got me through?       Thinking that if I could hang on,   one more day, maybe I'd be   rescued... and I'd see you again.
Well... I guess things don't   always turn out quite the way you   expect them to.
I know this isn't what you were   hoping for, but that doesn't mean   you can't make a future for   yourself.
For now, I think I'll just take   things one day at a time.
Captain Picard wanted me to find   out if you'd be willing to help us   retrieve the station's database.
I reconfigured that computer   system so many times they probably   can't make heads or tails of it.   I'd be happy to help.
Do you feel up to it?
Absolutely.
I'll tell the Captain.
Well... I have to go.
Deanna... I know it's been a long   time since we were together; I   know your feelings have changed.   But...
Mine haven't. I can't just give   up and accept that it's over... I   want to be with you again.
Good night, Wil...
Phase distortion is dropping --   the second transport window will   open in forty-two seconds.
How long will we have?
Thirty-six minutes, sir.
We are losing time. Lieutenant   Riker should be here.
Computer, where is Lieutenant --
Cancel inquiry.
You were supposed to report here   at eight hundred hours.
I'm sorry, I was --
I guess it's been a while since   you had to punch a clock.
Let's go.
Energize.
I shut down most of the consoles   to save power. I re-routed just   about everything through here.
Check out the primary EPS   coupling, see if you can get some   power to the rest of these   consoles.
I shunted the database to the main   core underneath the station.
Can we access it from here?
There's been a lot of seismic   activity over the years; if the   servo-links were damaged, we may   not be able to.
I'll try to tap into the command   pathways. See if you can disable   the file server.
I was thinking... we should   probably let Dad know what's   happened.
I'm sure he'll be thrilled to hear   there are two of us now.
I don't know. He and I patched up   a few things.
I've gotten by without talking to   him for a long time. I'm not   about to start now.
What made you contact him?
I didn't. He came to the   Enterprise to brief me when I was   offered the Aries.
What did he say when you turned   down the chance to command your   own ship?
He couldn't understand why I did   it.
For once he and I agree on   something.
The primary EPS coupling is fused.   It will have to be replaced.
I've accessed the command   pathways.
Let's see if that does the trick.
It's not working. The servo-link   must be damaged. We're going to   have to go under the station and   access the core directly.
We have less than three minutes   left.
Leave me here. If I start now,   I'll be finished by the time the   third window opens.
It's too dangerous. Our scans   show the caverns are unstable.
I've been down there dozens of   times; I know my way around.
We'll come back during the third   window with a new EPS coupling and   try to access the core from   another console up here.
Riker to Enterprise.
Enterprise, here.
We're ready to beam up.
You go ahead; I'll be finished by   the time you get back.
Hold it --
I gave you an order, Lieutenant.
Computer -- valerian root tea,   hot.
Meet me in Transporter Room Three   at nineteen hundred hours. It's   important.
It pulses unendingly   All through the night;   Seek out the crystal   That powers our flight.
Can I help you with something,   Counselor?
No -- thanks, anyway.
What the future holds   No one can know   But forward we look   And Forward you go...
The Janaran falls...
I remember. Where did you get   this?
I made it... a few years ago, down   on the station.
You made this?
You should have seen the first   two. It took me a while to get a   fine enough beam from the phaser.
It's lovely. Thank you.
Do you have time to sit and talk   for a while?
I wanted to remember... our last   night together.
How does it feel being with people   again?
Great...       A little strange...       For a long time, I did whatever I   wanted, whenever I wanted; it's   hard to get used to taking orders   again.
I can imagine.
I guess I'm going to have to if I   want to get my career going.
Is that what you've decided to do?
Don't you remember? How I wanted   to make Captain by the time I was   thirty-five?
I'm a little behind schedule, I'll   admit.
It's good that you don't feel...   set back.
I do. But I promised myself that   if I ever got out of there, I'd   make up for lost time.
Things are a little more   complicated than I thought they'd   be... but I'm not going to let   anything stop me from getting what   I want.
Thanks.

I can't tell you how many times I   thought about you... about us.   The first few weeks after the   evacuation, I was sure they'd find   a way to get through the   distortion field and come back for   me.       I even thought we'd meet on Risa   like we planned.       But the days kept going by and   nobody came. Then I realized why.   They thought I'd been killed in   the beam out. As far as anyone   knew, there was no one to come   back for.       I figured they probably held a   memorial service for me.   Somehow... it made me feel   better.
I can understand that.
You were there... all in black.       Very flattering on you, by the   way.
I'm sure I looked terrible -- my   eyes all red and swollen from   crying.

Sometimes I'd look up into the sky   and think that maybe, if I tried   hard enough, I could somehow make   you... feel my presence. I   thought that if I could let you   know I was still alive... maybe   you'd wait for me.       I know it's crazy, but there were   a few times that... that I   could've sworn --
What am I talking about?
The other day, when I told you how   Commander Riker and I didn't meet   on Risa... what I didn't say was   how disappointed I was.
You didn't have to. I knew.

I started hearing from him less   and less... I knew his career was   taking him away from me, but I   didn't want to believe it was   over. I spent a lot of time   thinking about him, wondering   where he was, what he was doing.
Sometimes I'd look up into the   sky... and imagine that he knew,   that he could sense me thinking   about him.
Who knows? Maybe one night... you   and I were both looking up at the   same star. You were thinking   about me... and in a way, I was   thinking about you.
You wanted to see me, Sir?
Yes, Number One. Come in.
Lieutenant Riker came to see me   about the away mission.
He believes the only way to   retrieve the database is by   directly accessing the main core   underneath the station.
Seismic activity has made the   caverns very unstable. In my   opinion, it's too risky.
He said he'd been down there quite   recently; he seems confident it   can be done safely.
There's a good chance we can   retrieve the database from one of   the consoles inside the station.
But if that doesn't work, it'll be   eight years before we get another   chance.
Lieutenant Riker's plan is more   dangerous, but I'll admit, it has   a better chance of succeeding.
Given the importance of this data,   I think it's worth the risk.
I'll look over the schematics and   draw up a mission plan.
I'm sure Lieutenant Riker would be   happy to help you with that.
I'll talk to him.
Lieutenant.
Sir.
I just spoke with the Captain   about your mission recommendation.   I'd appreciate it if next time you   came to me first.
I tried to, yesterday on the   station. You wouldn't hear me   out.
I heard you, Lieutenant. And I   rejected your plan.
May I ask what the Captain   decided?
He's going with your   recommendation, but that's not the   point.
Isn't it?

If you think I'm coming down on   you because the Captain overruled   me, think again. I happen to   disagree with his decision, but   he's my commanding officer and I   follow his orders. Just so   there's no confusion, I'm your   commanding officer and I expect   you to do the same. If you can't,   then you don't have a place on my   Away Team.
Yes, sir.
We're meeting in the Observation   lounge at fourteen hundred hours   to draw up a mission plan.
... we stayed in Ten Forward   talking for hours.
What happened then?
He walked me to my quarters.
What happened then?
Beverly --
I'm just asking.
It's been over between Wil and me   for a long time.
He's not Wil. He is, but -- you   know what I mean.
I do. But... it's hard for me to   separate my feelings for them.
Deanna... just because things   turned out the way they did   between you and Commander Riker...   that doesn't mean you shouldn't   let things with Lieutenant Riker   take their own course.
I should have known you'd   encourage me.
Isn't that why you brought it up?
Well... I think I'll call it a   day.
Beverly.
Bye.
Is that some form of tai-chi-chuan?
They're Klingon exercises,   actually. Lieutenant Worf has   been teaching a class.
The forms are very similar.
Do that last move again.
You just did the KoH-man-ara.
In tai-chi-chuan, it's called the   crane block.
I had no idea they were so   similar.
Let's try something else.
Very nice. Worf's a good teacher.
Hello, Wil.
Deanna...
I wanted to talk to you about   something.
If you want to be with him... you   don't have to ask my permission.
There's a certain look in your   eyes. I know... you used to have   it for me.
We've both had relationships with   other people before; but this is   different.
I didn't know how you would feel   about it.
Flattered.       Sort of.
It must be very strange for you.   I know it is for me.
Ever since he came aboard... I   keep finding myself thinking   about... the choices you and I   made.
Me too.
Just do one thing for me... be   careful.
Wil... I know you and he have had   some problems --
We have. But that's not what I'm   talking about.
If he'd made it off that planet   instead of me... don't you think   he would have made the same   choices I did?
I just don't want you to get   hurt... again.
Two pair.
Three of a kind.
I'd like to thank you both for   your very generous contributions.
Come in.
I thought -- you'd be alone.   Excuse me.
Why don't you join us?
Why not?
The game is five card draw, no   limit.
Lieutenant?
Three.
Mister Worf?
Four.
None for me.
The dealer will take two.
You control the bet.
Fifty.
Fold.
I'm in.
You didn't take any cards -- you   must be holding something. Why   not make it sweeter?
No thanks.
Playing it safe?
You in?
I will see your fifty and call.
Staying in will cost you another   hundred.
The dealer folds.
I spent too much time practicing   in the mirror to be fooled by that   face. You're bluffing.
If there's one thing I thought   would be clear by now, it's that   you and I play things a little   differently.
We'll see who comes out on top.
I thought you didn't mind settling   for second. Commander.

I've never settled for anything in   my life. I've made choices that   some people may not understand,   but I know what I want -- and I   know what I've got. You'd be   lucky to do as well.       Lieutenant.
I'll see your hundred and call.
Three hundred.
Now I know you're bluffing.
Are you in or not?
Why don't we just get this over   with? I'll match your three, and   raise you whatever you have left.
Well?
Take it. You win.
You were dealt the better hand,   Commander... all the way around.
Come in.
I'm sorry to just drop by like   this... but there's something   important I need to talk to you   about.
Captain Picard made some inquiries --   he helped me find a posting on the   Gandhi.
Considering how long I've been out   of commission, it's an amazing   opportunity.
When would you leave?
About a week.
I see.
Deanna...
After I've served on the ship for   six months, I'll be eligible to   bring family aboard.
If we got married...
You said those exact words to me   once before... when you first went   to serve on the Potemkin.
I remember.       I got held up for a while.
But if you hadn't... what would   have happened between us?
I wouldn't've made the mistake of   letting you go. I know that much.
I don't know if I can believe   that.
It took me a long time to get over   what happened between Commander   Riker and me. I don't know if I   want to put myself in that   position again.
I would never hurt you, Deanna.
It's not just that... I've worked   hard to make a life for myself on   the Enterprise. I'm happy here.
If the situation were different,   I'd stay here. But I can't... not   while he's aboard.
I know.
Are you saying it's over?
No.
I just don't know if I'm ready to   give up my life here.
Maybe we both need time to think.
Good night.
Captain's Log, supplemental. The   third transport window has opened   and the Away Team is making their   final attempt at retrieving the   database.
Once we restore the servo-link,   you can shunt the database up to   this console.
Ready, Commander?
You're with me, Lieutenant.
I thought Commander Data's   expertise in --
It doesn't take that much   expertise to repair a servo-link.   You and I can handle it.
I am curious about something,   Lieutenant. If you met a double   of yourself, would you find it   difficult to interact with him?
I think so.
Why?
I am not... easy to get along   with.
But Commander Riker and Lieutenant   Riker are. Yet they seem to have   trouble getting along with each   another.

I have found that humans value   their uniqueness, their sense that   they are different from every one   else. The existence of a double   would preclude that feeling.   Could that be the source of   friction?
Perhaps it is more a matter of   seeing something in your double...   something you don't like about   yourself.
There's the core over there.
Are you waiting for something?
Your order. Sir.
How would you like me to get   there?
You've been down here "dozens" of   times -- I'm sure you know the   best way.
Yes, sir. I do.
It's leaking ion radiation.
Why didn't you report this?
It wasn't there before; it must   have happened recently.
If we have to repair this conduit,   we won't have time to access the   computer core.
Scan it now.
It worked. Radiation levels are   dropping to normal levels.
Next time don't give up so easily.
I'm being pulled in --
Let go.
Let go.
One of us has to make it out of   here --
Take my hand --
No --
Take it!
Climb --
They have restored the servo-link   to the core. We can begin   downloading the database.
Initiating data transfer.
Captain's Log, Stardate 46920.1.   We have retrieved the database   from Nervala station and are   headed for our rendezvous with the   Gandhi.
Come in.
I understand the Gandhi is going   on a terraforming mission to the   Lagana Sector.
It'll take four months just to get   there.
I won't be going with you.
I guess I'm not surprised.
I'm not ready to give up my life   here.
Not yet.
Come in.
I'm sorry --
It's all right.
I wanted to give you something...
My quarters are full of things   that used to be yours. I figured   you should at least have this.
Thanks.
Good luck, Wil.
Actually... I was thinking of   going with the name Thomas.
Your middle name.
I guess we are different. I never   really cared for it.
I've always kind of liked it.
Well... I better get going.
Take care of her.
I waited a long time. I can wait   a little longer.
